content.description: Start in the undulating, overhanging #1-#2 size crack.  Follow this through the bulge and then cross discontinuous bushy cracks upward and left to the low angle slab.  Continue to anchors.
content.protection: Single set of gear to #3, bolted anchors

content.description:
Start with an all too short left leaning #3 hand crack.  Make a few fun moves before the crack disappears.  Continue up the ramp until you can gain two left leaning cracks on your right. Cross those cracks and continue up easy slab to the anchors.  

 This route has the most sustained climbing on the wall.
content.location: Left most crack on the lower tier.

content.description: A tough, overhung, boulder problem leads to easier climbing above.   Start in the shallow crack, pull your way over the bulge and follow the crack as it fades.  Clip the bolt and climb straight up over the second bulge to the low angle slab and anchors above.

A strange route. Make a couple moves stepping across a gap from a large boulder to the wall.  Crimp up and over the bulge and the follow low angle slab, generally straight up and over a second bulge to the top.
content.protection: Single bolt (protects the step across well) and single rack to #2, bolted anchors.
content.location: The right most bolt on lower tier protects the start. The route appears to begin by starting on the large boulder in the middle of the crossroads wall and stepping across.

content.description:
The lower Tier currently has 4 routes roughly twice as long as the upper tier. There are two sets of anchors easily accessed on each end of the comfy ledge at the base of the upper tier.  Fork in the road, Crossroads, and Overpass share the anchors on climber’s left while Cheryl’s drive by uses the anchors on Climber’s Right. 

The routes are really 15-20 foot boulder problems with easy slab above but still worth checking out.
